title: Morgan Stanley, Citigroup, Plug Power: What to Watch in the Stock Market Today; Bank of America shares gained after its earnings report; Alcoa shares were following aluminum prices higher
text:
* Wells Fargo reported a 59% rise in profit in the third quarter, boosted by a release of funds it had set aside for potential loan losses during the pandemic. Its revenue slipped 2% but still came above analysts' estimates.

* Bank of America reported earnings per share that beat analysts' estimates. The bank released $1.1 billion of its reserve in the third quarter, citing asset quality improvements.

* Citigroup posted a sizable beat on earnings per share and a 48% rise in net income. The bank's CEO said the recovery from the pandemic is driving corporate consumer confidence.

* The Wall Street Journal reported that Boeing is dealing with a new defect on its 787 Dreamliner, the latest in a series of production slip-ups that have delayed aircraft deliveries and drawn scrutiny.

* Domino's Pizza posted revenue and U.S. same-store sales that missed expectations.

* UnitedHealth raised its full-year guidance for earnings. It said its revenue growth was driven by higher insurance memberships.

* Some of agriculture-equipment maker Deere's employees went on strike for higher pay.

* Walgreens Boots Alliance posted a profit jump and earnings per share that came above Wall Street's estimates.

* Shares of United Parcel Service rose after an equity research analyst at Stifel raised their price target and rating on the stock.

* Fuel-cell company Plug Power said it would work with Airbus to study the feasibility of bringing green hydrogen to aircraft and airports.

* Lordstown Motors hired a new finance chiefin the wake of the electric-truck startup's recent liquidity problems.

* Online furniture retailer Wayfair's stock was downgraded by equity research analysts at Jefferies and Morgan Stanley.

* Aluminum producer Alcoa's shares were rising as aluminum prices climbed. The company is also scheduled to report earnings after markets close.

Chart of the Day

* Since neither Hong Kong or Singapore has previously allowed them, SPACs sponsored by Asian investors flocked to the U.S. to raise money. Since the start of last year, 35 such SPACs have raised a total of $6.8 billion by going public on American stock exchanges, according to Dealogic. This may be about to change as the Asian finance hubs move forward with plans to allow SPAC listings.

Write to Anna Hirtenstein at anna.hirtenstein@wsj.com

Morgan Stanley, Citigroup, Plug Power: What to Watch in the Stock Market Today
